MDP solver algorithms¶

pymdp._value_iteration.value_iteration(mdp: pymdp.mdp.MarkovDecisionProcess, epsilon)[source]¶

Performs infinite horizon value iteration for a given MDP with a numerical error term epsilon.

pymdp._policy_iteration.can_improve(improvements)[source]¶

A boolean check on whether any improvement is actually possible from the present policy.

pymdp._policy_iteration.determine_improvements(mdp, value)[source]¶

Computes, for each state, the set of all associated actions for which the value function would increase if the policy were to adopt them.

The state gets skipped if no improvements can be made in it. Thus the returned improvements are only those which strictly improve the policy’s associated value function.

pymdp._policy_iteration.improve_policy(mdp, policy, value, improvements)[source]¶

Given a policy, value function, and set of state-action combinations that can modify the policy so that the value function increases strictly, do just that.

pymdp._policy_iteration.policy_iteration(mdp: pymdp.mdp.MarkovDecisionProcess)[source]¶

Performs policy iteration on a given infinite horizon MDP.

pymdp._policy_iteration.policy_reward(mdp, policy)[source]¶

For each $x in X$ $$ r(phi)_x = sum_{y in X} P(y mid x, phi(x)) r(y, phi(x)) $$

pymdp._policy_iteration.policy_transition(mdp, policy)[source]¶

Computes the transition matrix corresponding to a particular policy function, so that the (i,j)th entry in the matrix corresponds to the probability of arriving at state i from state j through policy[j].

pymdp._policy_iteration.solve_for_value(mdp, policy)[source]¶

Solves the system $$ (I - eta P(policy)) v = r(policy) $$ for the value function v.
